Figure 1 shows the convergence trajectories of MAML and TR-MAML when K=5ğ¾5K=5. Each plot entails estimating the current modelâ€™s MSE on each task by sampling 5,000 task instances across all 100 meta-training tasks (for an average of 50 instances per task), and separately across all 490 meta-testing tasks.
The leftmost plot shows the average and maximum MSE over each of the 100 meta-training tasksâ€™ estimated MSE vs the number of iterations, and the middle-left plot shows the same statistics over the 490 meta-testing tasks. During meta-training, TR-MAML sacrifices average for worst-case task performance. However, its focus on task-robustness yields more uniform performance across all tasks, allowing TR-MAML to outperform MAML on the hardest meta-test tasks while nearly matching MAMLâ€™s average performance after the distributional shift. TR-MAMLâ€™s more uniform performance for K=5ğ¾5K=5 is captured in the middle-right plot of Figure 1, which shows the standard deviation across the meta-testing task MSEs vs the number of iterations, and the rightmost plot of Figure 1, a histogram of the average MSEs among the 490 meta-test tasks, computed using 5,000 total task instances.
Table 1 tells a similar story for the Kâˆˆ{5,10}ğ¾510K\in\{5,10\}-shot cases by giving the average, maximum, and standard deviation of the MSEs among the 490 meta-test tasks after full meta-training, where the statistics are again empirical averages over 5,000 task instances.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2: Omniglot Nğ‘N-way, Kğ¾K-shot classification accuracies (%). After meta-training, 5,000 few-shot classification problems (task instances) are sampled uniformly from the 25 alphabets (tasks) used for meta-training, likewise for the 20 new meta-testing alphabets. For each alphabet, the average accuracy on task instances from that alphabet is computed, and statistics are taken across these average accuracies. â€˜Weighted Meanâ€™ weighs the alphabet accuracies by the meta-training distribution, which corresponds to the quantity MAML aims to optimize, whereas â€˜Meanâ€™ weighs all alphabets equally. â€˜Worstâ€™ is the minimum alphabet accuracy, and â€˜Std. Dev.â€™ is the standard deviation across the alphabet accuracies, with 95% confidence intervals given over three full runs for all statistics.
references:
We use the same 4-layer CNN used in the original MAML paper (Finn etÂ al., 2017). After 60,000 meta-training iterations, we evaluate the models yielded by MAML and TR-MAML on 5,000 Nğ‘N-way, Kğ¾K-shot classification problems from the 20 meta-test alphabets, as well as 5,000 problems from the meta-training alphabets.
Table 2 shows statistics taken over the average accuracy on task instances from each alphabet for different combinations of Nğ‘N and Kğ¾K.
Note that the empirical distribution of meta-training alphabets becomes more skewed as Nğ‘N increases, causing MAML to focus on a smaller subset of the meta-training alphabets and further disregard worst-case alphabet performance. In contrast, TR-MAML prioritizes performance on all of the meta-training alphabets equally, leading to an â€˜alphabet-robustâ€™ model that typically outperforms MAML on new alphabets, not only in the worst case but also on average across alphabets. Additional experimental results are given in Appendix J.

A10.T3.caption: Table 3: Omniglot Nğ‘N-way, Kğ¾K-shot classification accuracies (%). After meta-training, 5,000 few-shot classification problems (task instances) are sampled uniformly from the 25 alphabets (tasks) used for meta-training, likewise for the 20 new meta-testing alphabets. For each alphabet, the average accuracy on task instances from that alphabet is computed, and statistics are taken across these average accuracies. â€˜Weighted Meanâ€™ weighs the alphabet accuracies by the meta-training distribution, which corresponds to the quantity MAML aims to optimize, whereas â€˜Meanâ€™ weighs all alphabets equally. â€˜Worstâ€™ is the minimum alphabet accuracy, and â€˜Std. Dev.â€™ is the standard deviation across the alphabet accuracies, with 95% confidence intervals given over three full runs for all statistics.
references: For the image classification experiments on the Omniglot dataset, we adapted the codebase from the repository available at https://github.com/AntreasAntoniou/HowToTrainYourMAMLPytorch that implements in Pytorch https://pytorch.org/ the experiments in the paper (Antoniou etÂ al., 2019). Again we kept most of the default parameters consistent. The Adam optimizer was used for the meta-update of wğ‘¤w and vanilla SGD was used to update pğ‘p. We set Î·p=2.0Ã—10âˆ’5subscriptğœ‚ğ‘2.0superscript105\eta_{p}=2.0\times 10^{-5} for the 5-way experiments, Î·p=1.6Ã—10âˆ’5subscriptğœ‚ğ‘1.6superscript105\eta_{p}=1.6\times 10^{-5} for the 10-way experiments, and Î·p=1.0Ã—10âˆ’5subscriptğœ‚ğ‘1.0superscript105\eta_{p}=1.0\times 10^{-5} for the 20-way experiments. In all cases, we set J=10ğ½10J=10. After meta-training for 60,000 iterations with a batch size of 8, the most recent meta-trained model was evaluated on both the meta-testing and meta-training tasks (alphabets). One step of SGD was used for both meta-training and meta-testing in all experiments. Images were augmented by rotations of 90 degrees, with augmented images considered part of the same class (thus there were 20Ã—4=802048020\times 4=80 images per class), but each image in each class in each task instance was rotated by the same amount. Additional results for the 101010-way classification case are shown in Table 3.
